provenance.name: Tate Collection
provenance.note: Acquired, and probably commissioned, from Blake by Thomas Butts, c. 1799-1800; by inheritance in 1845 to Thomas Butts, Jr.; by inheritance in 1862 to Captain F. J. Butts; sold from the Butts collection, Sotheby's, 24 June 1903, lot 8 (£80 to "Knowles," probably a dealer); the dealer Carfax & Co. by 1904; F. P. Osmaston by 1906; sold from his collection in 1914 to the National Art Collections Fund and given to the Tate Gallery.

objnote.p: Blake signed the work with his monogram lower right; see the textual transcription. The painting was restored in 1914 by "W. G. Littlejohn" (Butlin 390, but possibly Stanley William Littlejohn) and again in 1958.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This design illustrates King David seeing Bathsheba bathing (2 Samuel 11:2). A nude female figure with long, curly hair, evidently Bathsheba, stands at the center of the design. She faces forward, with one leg extended backward and on tiptoe. Bathsheba looks down to her left and has both arms raised at 45 degrees, one behind each of the children that flank her. Her right hand touches the back or shoulder of the child to the left. To Bathsheba's left is a nude child facing away but looking up and to the right at Bathsheba. The left leg is extended backward and is on tiptoe. The child's gender is not clearly indicated. To the right of Bathsheba's is a nude girl with long hair. She faces forward, but looks slightly left. Her right leg is extended slightly backward and is on tiptoe. She may be partly clothed by a long gown or drapery that rests on her shoulders and fall below her right hand, which may be holding the cloth. In her left hand she holds by a handle a triangular vessel of some sort. To the left sits a nude woman, with her feet in the water of the bath. She has long curly hair and rests her right arm on her right knee; her left arm is raised and she may hold an object, possibly a washing cloth, in her left hand. Her right hand rests on the top of a covered vase or vessel of some sort. She faces forward and left, looking up at the three standing figures. The four nude figures are standing or sitting on some rocks(?) by the edge of a pond or bath. There are carved wooden(?) columns to the right and the left of the bathing area. The columns on the left have leafy vines growing up them. To the right of the girl grow a number of flowering plants. In the background grow some trees or leafy but indeterminate vegetation. In the upper right corner of the design, King David stands "on the roof of the king's house" (2 Samuel 11:2). He is dressed in a gown and cloak, and wears a crown on his head. His body is facing partly to the right, but his head is turned left to look at the bathers. His arms are raised in front of him horizontally, his right extended over his chest. His left palm is raised and turned out toward the viewer. His gestures suggest surprise. The sky backing this scene is cloudy with a sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude female figure with long, curly hair, evidently Bathsheba, stands at the center of the design. She faces forward, with one leg extended backward and on tiptoe. Bathsheba looks down to her left and has both arms raised at 45 degrees, one behind each of the children that flank her. Her right hand touches the back or shoulder of the child to the left.

To Bathsheba's left is a nude child facing away but looking up and to his right at Bathsheba. The figure's hair is short, possibly curly, and possibly arranged into a bun. The left leg is extended backward and is on tiptoe. The child's gender is not clearly indicated.

To Bathsheba's right is a nude girl with long hair. She faces forward, but looks slightly left. Her right leg is extended slightly backward and is on tiptoe. She may be partly clothed by a long gown or drapery that rests on her shoulders and falls below her right hand, which may be holding the cloth. In her left hand she hold by a handle a vessel of some sort.

To the left sits a nude woman, with her feet in the water of the bath. She has long curly hair and rests her right arm on her right knee; her left arm is raised and she holds an object, possibly a washing cloth, in her left hand. She faces forward and left, looking up at the three standing figures. Her right hand rests on the top of a covered vase or vessel of some sort.

The four nude figures are standing or sitting on some rocks(?) by the edge of a pond or bath. There are carved wooden(?) columns to the right and the left of the bathing area. Horizontal beams, perhaps part of a roof, appear at the top of the columns. The plinth-like bases of the columns are pictured.
Bathsheba's bath appears as a strip of water below the standing figures.

The columns on the left have leafy vines growing up them. To the right of the standing figures grow a number of flowering plants. Some of the flowers may be lilies; others are perhaps roses (top left and lower right). In the background grow some trees or leafy but indeterminate vegetation.

David, standing upper right, is dressed in a gown and cloak, and wears a crown on his head. He is bearded and probably has long hair. His body is facing to the right, but his head is turned left to look at the bathers. His arms are raised in front of him horizontally, with the right arm extended across his chest. His left hand is raised, palm out toward the viewer. His gestures suggest surprise.
In the upper right corner of the design, David stands on the "roof of the king's house" (2 Samuel 11:2).
The sky backing this scene is cloudy with a sunrise or sunset.
